title: Trump’s DOA peace plan
text:
A peace plan for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict unveiled by US President Donald Trump looks dead on arrival. True to his bombastic style, he called it the “deal of the century". It includes the proposal of a future Palestinian state, but also seems to let Israel retain control of Jerusalem as its capital and also of annexed territories in the West Bank where Jewish settlements have been built. It’s no surprise that the deal was swiftly rejected by Palestinian leaders.

Maybe it was just a political game. Trump, who is suspected of letting his son-in-law Jared Kushner determine White House policy in the region, is undergoing an impeachment trial in Washington DC. Israeli leader Benjamin Netanyahu, with whom Trump shared many a photo op, is in legal trouble for corruption. Netayanhu is also in campaign mode—for a third election after two earlier ones failed to deliver a verdict in any Israeli party’s favour. The proposal seems aimed at the two leaders’ respective constituencies.

For decades, Palestinians have been sceptical of the US being an even-handed mediator in the conflict. Trump, though, doesn’t even bother to disguise a pro-Israel tilt. Kushner, meanwhile, has been leading efforts that effectively seek to have big money buy out Palestinian claims. Given the smouldering history of the stand-off and religious sensitivities over the status of Jerusalem—especially the site of the Al Aqsa mosque and Western Wall—a cavalier approach would not work. If the US truly wants the issue resolved, it needs buy-in from both sides, and that takes real effort.
